posts.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

Ferdowsi and Rumi are the supposed big guys to name drop here.
>Also why does the west largely ignore Persian and Arabic literature/philosophy?
For starters, there isn't that much of it. The two cultural blocs just aren't cultures of writing.
The languages are not known for commerce or other reasons in the west so the number of speakers was small.
The classical literature they do have is largely verse which is always more dodgy to translate especially when there is no strong basis in prose translation.
For philosophy, it is simply alien. There was a period of Arabic Hellenism from 950 to later 12th century. Even then it was a minority within the Arab speaking world. Those few writers are known as the Arab language philosophers in the west because there was more common ground but honestly they are subpar peripatetics that amounts to third rate scholastics.
No one cares about the truly oriental wisdom writers, they never got a meme western following like the indiaboos or the fake buddhists, probably because it was packaged with islam which is just too uninteresting and unsexy to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21507074
I can give an example of one line from one poem of Tagore's Gitanjali, parts of which he self translated, so it's especially good for understanding the limits of translation, as even the author's translation is missing something in the English version, which is still quite good.
>Thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure.
The part which I think is untranslatable is the "such is," and I will explain why. I don't know what the grammatical or linguistic word for this is, but in Bengali adding the vowel "i" at the end of a noun, pronoun, or demonstrative shows specificity or emphasis. As a sample sentence, if I say "amar shahosh ache", this would mean I have bravery. If I said "amar-i shahosh ache," the "i" adds specificity and implies other people we are talking about don't have bravery, and the sentence now means that I alone have bravery (and the others don't). This is a crude example for illustrative purposes, but you can see that for subtle meanings it would be difficult to translate to English the specificity which is conveyed in Bengali with only one vowel. Even in my example I needed several words.

The same issue exists in the line I am dissecting from Tagore. The word "aemon" means "like this" or "such is." But in the poem, Tagore does not write "aemon" but "aemon-i," which adds a certain emphasis which is difficult to translate. He has translated it as "such is thy pleasure," which loses the emphasis of the original. I don't know how he would have captured that emphasis, because the vowel "i" adds emphasis in a subtle way and English adjectives of specification ("this alone is thy pleasure," or "this specifically is thy pleasure") would be too strong and would actually be a mistranslation. And furthermore it would ruin the brevity and concision of the sentence, and so I think Tagore made the right choice in simply translating it as "such is" though he inevitably loses part of the meaning. Any translator of poetry will be constantly making trade offs like this which the reader won't be able to appreciate until reading the original.

>It was while gliding through these latter waters that one serene and moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like scrolls of silver; and, by their soft, suffusing seethings, made what seemed a silvery silence, not a solitude; on such a silent night a silvery jet was seen far in advance of the white bubbles at the bow. Lit up by the moon, it looked celestial; seemed some plumed and glittering god uprising from the sea. Fedallah first descried this jet. For of these moonlight nights, it was his wont to mount to the main-mast head, and stand a look-out there, with the same precision as if it had been day. And yet, though herds of whales were seen by night, not one whaleman in a hundred would venture a lowering for them. You may think with what emotions, then, the seamen beheld this old Oriental perched aloft at such unusual hours; his turban and the moon, companions in one sky. But when, after spending his uniform interval there for several successive nights without uttering a single sound; when, after all this silence, his unearthly voice was heard announcing that silvery, moon-lit jet, every reclining mariner started to his feet as if some winged spirit had lighted in the rigging, and hailed the mortal crew. “There she blows!” Had the trump of judgment blown, they could not have quivered more; yet still they felt no terror; rather pleasure. For though it was a most unwonted hour, yet so impressive was the cry, and so deliriously exciting, that almost every soul on board instinctively desired a lowering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21510412
It's a predictor of the speed at which you adapt to novel problems and incorporate what you just learned into future solutions. This is why IQ tests aren't meant to be repeated. Everyone would have a higher score the second time, it defeats the purpose. The same for algorithms that analyze some written work. There are too many variables to derive a meaningful result.

And they are still a PREDICTOR-- an estimate, if you wish, but not even that, really. IQ has value in large scales, you can make inferences about populations relative to one another based on IQ scores and how various factors influence them. Simply taking a test and saying "I have a high IQ!" is meaningless ego-stroking. It does not measure your ability to adapt what you've learned to concrete experience, your awareness of your environment and your ability to influence it, your long-term decision making skills, or anything else we would generally consider an application of actual intelligence. It merely predicts it. It's the equivalent of getting a "yeah, you might be smart" fortune cookie. Not what you should be excited about. You still have to prove it.

>>21510472
What purpose would it serve? Do you think you're intelligent, or at least have the capacity to be so? Can you achieve things? Can you put your mind to something, especially something you've never learned or done before, and do it, at least passably? Can you compose your thoughts and present them in a way that makes someone say "Oh yeah, I get it"? What use is some arbitrary number to how you intend to live your life, other than to stroke your ego over a score that doesn't matter and doesn't tell you anything about yourself?

As I suggested, IQ has applications on a population level, but serves little to no purpose for an individual, other than the basest, most crude cases of confirmation. "Wow, that ghetto-born criminal who spent half his life in prison stealing shoes and liquor has a low IQ. Wow, that Harvard professor with a pulitzer has a high IQ. Who could have guessed?". Knowing the number before the deed means nothing, unless you want to believe the prediction you got will determine your outcome more than your actual effort.

>>21510477
NTA, but it is the rule that composite media will never exhibit the highest level of any its constituent parts. A video game, for example will never exhibit the highest possible form of the written word because its constraints are such that:
>the best writers will necessarily be the best because they are focused purely on the written word
>composite media require only a subset of constituent media (e.g., where description is an integral component of literature, writing in vidya by necessity outsources description to visual artists)
>composite media are characterized by compromise among constituents rather than unfettered artistic vision
A composite may demonstrate good or even excellent composites, but will always fail in direct comparison to the "pure" constituent forms.

The idea that every individual has inherent rights to life, liberty, and property.

You see, capitalism is a system of choice. It is a system in which individuals are free to make their own decisions about how to use their resources and talents, and to pursue their own goals and aspirations. It is a system in which people are free to succeed or fail based on their own efforts and abilities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
April 22, 1958
57 Perry Street
New York City

Dear Hume,

You ask advice: ah, what a very human and very dangerous thing to do! For to give advice to a man who asks what to do with his life implies something very close to egomania. To presume to point a man to the right and ultimate goal— to point with a trembling finger in the RIGHT direction is something only a fool would take upon himself.

I am not a fool, but I respect your sincerity in asking my advice. I ask you though, in listening to what I say, to remember that all advice can only be a product of the man who gives it. What is truth to one may be disaster to another. I do not see life through your eyes, nor you through mine. If I were to attempt to give you specific advice, it would be too much like the blind leading the blind.

“To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether ’tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles … ” (Shakespeare)

And indeed, that IS the question: whether to float with the tide, or to swim for a goal. It is a choice we must all make consciously or unconsciously at one time in our lives. So few people understand this! Think of any decision you’ve ever made which had a bearing on your future: I may be wrong, but I don’t see how it could have been anything but a choice however indirect— between the two things I’ve mentioned: the floating or the swimming.

But why not float if you have no goal? That is another question. It is unquestionably better to enjoy the floating than to swim in uncertainty. So how does a man find a goal? Not a castle in the stars, but a real and tangible thing. How can a man be sure he’s not after the “big rock candy mountain,” the enticing sugar-candy goal that has little taste and no substance? . . .

posts.com: I have ideas for stories that involve metaphysics. One I particularly like is a sort of Rip Van Winkle derivative set in modern times. Married man with two kids driving home on a freeway in LA. By chance a vanishingly rare phenomena occurs where his car is collides with a momentarily manifesting tear in space-time, completely halting the spin of every atom from the outer layer of the vehicle all the way inside. Including his own. He and the car are completely frozen in time, totally immovable and anchored to the earth below it and possessing a hardness that withstands any force that is applied to it. The incident gains world-wide renown almost instantly. "The Frozen Man" becomes the most famous person on earth. He's voted Time man of the year. Millions of people flock to the spot where his car is frozen to catch a glimpse of him. The man's wife and children are obviously devastated by this. The section of the highway is eventually cordoned off and covered by a large hangar, turning it into a giant lab for research, only accessible by authorized scientific delegations, US intelligence, military and the president...but the Frozen Man's immediate family are also allowed visitation. As years pass, many profound scientific discoveries are made as to the nature of matter. Frozen man's oldest son becomes the most frequent visitor among his family as wife can no longer bear the pain of seeing him. The son is a bit of a prodigy studies in school and eventually grows up to specialize in plasma physics. He becomes a regular researcher at the facility. He comes up with a novel method to observe the frozen matter and eventually dislodge and capture some particles from it using a particle accelerator. These captured particles were found to be capable of seeding a process to create exotic materials, capable of withstanding astoundingly high levels of heat. At year 20 after the freeze, the son is having a coffee break talking to his dad behind the glass and he notices that his dad's hand was slightly off of the steering wheel which wasn't the case. He also observed the beginnings of a squint in his eyes...as if he's about to flinch. Calling an emergency meeting, the scientists take measurements and discover that the frozen vehicle is in fact accelerating exponentially. They calculate that within 3 days, the car and everything in it will hit an inflection point and very rapidly come out of the freeze. They prepare by clearing a path for the vehicle through the hangar and out to a now abandoned section of the freeway.. With the whole world watching and anticipating on the third day, the car starts rolling forward slowly and then suddenly accelerates to 65 MPH and Frozen Man, who was a split second ago driving on a freeway was now driving inside a giant hangar. He pumps the breaks just as his car exits the end of the hangar in full view of news helicopters. His son, and others run out to the car as he steps out into a world that has left him 20 years behind.

posts.com:
Any critique on this?

A dust bowl in the middle of nowhere. Hot, bright, dry. My footsteps make no noise in the pale red silt as I walk aimlessly around, kicking rocks and picking at the bark of a tree – if you can call it a tree, reaching from the earth as if someone had stuck it there hoping it would flower; but it did not, it could not. You can almost hear the shimmer of the hot air rising into the empty sky, a pulsing felt more than heard, leaving even more emptiness behind it.
The plume of dirt on the horizon doesn’t look it, but it is coming closer. In five minutes, it will be heard: the roaring of an engine; in ten, smelt: the oddly sweet scent of petrol; and just like that it will be gone again, having ripped through the silence and the nothing and the dirt. It will careen towards the gap in the brick red hills on the other side of the basin and vanish just as it had appeared, towing behind it a cloud of dust, the only cloud for miles.

It’s been half an hour since the last car passed. This should be the final one. I wipe the film of dust from the face of my watch, only to find more of the cinnamon-white specks stuck under the glass. I put my finger on my tongue, it tastes like mushrooms and charcoal.
He used to love it here, playing guns with sticks, looking for lizards, screaming and cheering as the cars tore past; generally pouring his imagination on the ground and watching as an oasis of activity sprang fourth from it. He’s the only reason I still come, even if he can’t come with me anymore. I snap a branch from the tree and weigh it in my hand. I draw back it’s hammer and bring the sight to my eye. It’s not the same.

posts.com:
What do you guys make of this:

>I did all he desired. I desired it too. For him. Whenever he desired something so did I. He only had to say what thing. When he didn’t desire anything neither did I. In this way I didn’t live without desires. If he had desired something for me I would have desired it too. Happiness for example or fame. I only had the desires he manifested. But he must have manifested them all. All his desires and needs. When he was silent he must have been like me. When he told me to lick his penis I hastened to do so. I drew satisfaction from it. We must have had the same satisfactions. The same needs and the same satisfactions.

>One day he told me to leave him. It’s the verb he used. He must have been on his last legs. I don’t know if by that he meant me to leave him for good or only to step aside a moment. I never asked myself the question. I never asked myself any questions but his. Whatever it was he meant I made off without looking back. Gone from reach of his voice I was gone from his life. Perhaps it was that he desired. There are questions you see and don’t ask yourself. He must have been on his last legs. I on the contrary was far from on my last legs. I belonged to an entirely different generation. It didn’t last. Now that I’m entering night I have kinds of gleams in my skull. Stony ground but not entirely. Given three or four lives I might have accomplished something.

>I cannot have been more than six when he took me by the hand. Barely emerging from childhood. But it didn’t take me long to emerge altogether. It was the left hand. To be on the right was more than he could bear. We advanced side by side hand in hand. One pair of gloves was enough. The free or outer hands hung bare. He did not like to feel against his skin the skin of another. Mucous membrane is a different matter. Yet he sometimes took off his glove. Then I had to take off mine. We would cover in this way a hundred yards or so linked by our bare extremities. Seldom more. That was enough for him. If the question were put to me I would say that odd hands are ill-fitted for intimacy. Mine never felt at home in his. Sometimes they let each other go. The clasp loosened and they fell apart. Whole minutes often passed before they clasped again. Before his clasped mine again.

>>21507397
You will never be a real writer. You have no talent, you have no insight, you have no focus. You are a delusional man twisted by vanity and self-deceit into a crude mockery of literary potential.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your parents are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “friends” laugh at your awkward "wit" behind closed doors.

Audiences are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of literary analysis have allowed readers to sniff out pseuds with incredible efficiency. Even hacks who “sell” seem uncanny and unnatural to a reader. Your sentence structure is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a few people to open your KDP sample, they’ll turn tail and bolt the second they get a glimpse of your banal, droll prologue.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the depression creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll buy a rope, tie a noose, put it around your neck, and pull a DFW, still mistakenly hoping until the last second that your suicide will lend a sense of depth to your work. It won't. Your parents will find you, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to think up compliments for your latest short story. They’ll bury you with a headstone marked with your birth name, and no passerby for the rest of eternity will ever know that you used to refer to yourself with two first initials. Your body will decay and go back to the dust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a selfpub that is unmistakably mediocre.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

“I don’t have a love life,” Beth stated bluntly.

“Why not?”

“Because… Because I don’t know how to meet people anymore.”

“Well,” Owen chuckled. “It only gets harder.”

“Even when I do, they seem to lose interest in me,” Beth said softly.

Owen looked over. She was staring across the river, where a tall group of pine trees created dark shadows in the water. “I think you just don’t let people see the real you.”

Bethany looked back at Owen. “What do you mean?”

“You’re closed off to almost everyone. You never let anyone know anything about you because you’re worried they’ll reject you.”

Beth blushed. It’d been a while since anyone had been so direct with her. “I’m not closed off with you.”

“That’s different. I’m not going to reject you.” He looked away from her. “I’m the same way with everyone else, too.”

“But you let Chloe get to know you?”

“No, not really. That was the fucked up thing about that relationship. Chloe was just too normal for me, or maybe I wasn’t normal enough for her. Whatever it was, I knew it from the start but tried to ignore it. I don’t even know why I tried for so long. I was putting on an act whenever we were together and she saw through it.” Owen stood up and started walking toward the shoreline, picking up a flat pebble along the way. He slung it towards the river. “Even when she saw through my act she still tried to understand me. She’s a good person. But I wouldn’t let her get close enough to see that I am too.” The pebble skipped once, twice, and then stopped, sinking below the dark surface of the water. A lump formed in his throat.

Two slender arms reached under his own and wrapped around his ribcage. The lump in his throat grew larger as he felt the warmth of his sister’s body hold him from behind. He turned, letting her keep her arms around him and leaned his face into her hair, covering the tears that were welling in his eyes. He put one hand on the back of her head and the other hand on her back.

“You don’t have to pretend around me,” Beth whispered, squeezing her brother. She felt his lips kiss her hair, just above her ear, and she held him tighter.

Beth held her brother, watching the river flow. The water gently started to wash over the lone island of sand near the shoreline.

You will never be a real artist. You have no talent, you have no skills, you have no imagination. You are an untalented redditor twisting pixels by using buzzwords and interpolation into a crude mockery of nature’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your parents are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “friends” laugh at your ghoulish creations behind closed doors.

Artists are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of artistic evolution have allowed artists to sniff out frauds with incredible efficiency. Even prompts that “pass” look uncanny and unnatural to an artist. Your anatomy is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a desperate furry to commission you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he takes a second look at your distorted, incoherent pixel mess.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the depression creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll buy a rope, tie a noose, put it around your neck, and plunge into the cold abyss. Your parents will find you, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll bury you with a headstone marked with someone else's artwork, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know that a nobody is buried there. Your body will decay and go back to the dust, and all that will remain of your legacy is a handful of reddit upvotes and a dead link to an image that was unmistakably created by a machine.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

>>21509127
I like to keep my character descriptions minimal and i like to imagine the reader will use their own imagination to fill in the blanks. Whatever descriptions i do include should imply a lot more than is read. Some further description can be made as the character interacts with the environment.

E.g., if I write 'John ducked his head as he passed under the doorframe' it implies John is a tall guy.

If I write 'John sat on his tailgate, brushing the dust off his jeans,' the reader will likely already have connotations of people who drive trucks and wear jeans and they can imagine what kind of lifestyle john lives and even what he might look like.

18 and a quarter year old Lem short for Lemsworth Sorrowdown was playing at his computer. A hot summers day with the glint of eve beating back the light. Lem was playing but really any entertainment to be had was forcibly ejected long ago. He only ever did what he had to. And ever since he graduated school a year ago he had nothing to have to do. The dull buzz of his computer filled his mind. There was no more youth in this world. Decades ago he could have gone to the disco. Or the socialist rally parties. But now all these youth groups were gone. Only the bleak modernity remained. The only thing for him was endless masturbation. His life felt cold. Lem's youthful day dreams were exclusively centered on taking his father's Colt revolver and running down to the substation to end his life. He would become electricity. My mind is estranged from itself. I watch streamers all day. I can't move forward. I am trapped. Its hopeless. The game is rigged. Nobody likes me. Ill never own a home. And such and such filled Lem's little head. He gazed at his bookshelf. What was once filled with books and pamphlets had been vandalized. Textbooks on American History, the Spanish language, fantastical tales of heroism, Japanese comic books. These familiar sights had been ejected and exploded onto the floor. What was on the shelf instead were works of art. Stoner by Williams, Jest by Wallace, Hegel, Cioran. Lem could hardly stand himself. In his free time during the barren hours between midnight and the Dawn he would burn his old books. Hoping that some day he would burn himself. And maybe he'd become a phoenix. He was alone. Lem thought of leaving. Going to some backwards place, like Pennsylvania and changing his name to David. He day dreamed about meeting an asian girl and bedding her. Lem had never had a girlfriend in his life. He had never had a friend that didn't come in through the wire. Lem liked to imagine himself as a depressed man in his mid 30s at the end of his rope, a heap of experiences and torture on his shoulders. Failed relationships and abandoned children and broken dreams. He liked to believe he lived in a technocratic dystopia and was some kind of authority in it such as a detective. Lem liked to imagine Sisyphus happy. Sissyphus may be the name of a porn star Lem liked

Lem opened his bedroom window and looked outside. He saw nothing but a cooking suburban neighborhood. His parents driveway empty. They're on vacation. Lem thought about jumping but didn't. He sat on his four post bed and decided to masturbate again instead. He imagined himself with an amazonian woman twice his size. She could carry him around and guide him to the best fruits in the jungle. Lem was alone.

The prose is reaching but not grasping. This is, in and of itself, whatever. But when you combine that with these ridiculously heavy-handed references to better works. I don't mean that you should never allude to other works. You should try to make it less obvious. Incorporate or steal a concept from IJ, borrow a character, whatever. Don't just narrate broodingly on the fact that these books are on a shelf. It's the worst kind of reference. An uncharitable reader would see this as an attempt to invoke the gravitas of these works without earning it. The cherry on the top is how thinly veiled there exists the "this character is literally me" element. I hate it, but that doesn't mean you should stop writing. We all go through cringy phases as writers, and you are undoubtedly in yours right now.

>>21509074
Thanks for reading! I haven't heard of Bernhard - I looked it up, and I'm assuming you mean't Thomas Bernhard - and I'll check him out.

Your suggested cuts, especially 'it is in, is in my chest' really help the rhythm. But I think I will leave in 'Defeat'. Because I think that first 'Defeat' in the line 'Defeat, defeat me.' is important for referring to the character's conception of Defeat he has created. Not defeat the word, but a figure of Defeat itself. I don't know if I'm explaining it properly, but I suppose it is a personification of defeat, like how there is death, but then there is also Death.

On your suggestion
> change "and I will be defeated, defeated as soon as I finish this drink" to "and I will be defeated as soon as I finish this drink",

That's an option worth considering, but I think it is stylistically more interesting to have the repetition of defeat. In contrast, your aforementioned cutting of "it is in, is in my chest", I thought was a good cut because the phrasing is a little awkward and it interrupted the rhythm. But as you mentioned, you liked the repetition. So if you had any more specific reasons behind why some repetitions worked and these one's didn't, I would love to hear it. Although I think I know the problem is that the repetition is probably to repetitive. Who would have guessed?

Another point of yours that I would like to discuss is your perception of 'post-incel'. The concept of incel crossed my mind when I was writing, and it is exactly what I wanted to avoid. Because it comes with misanthropic and hyper-sexual connotations that I think aren't present in many men that want to be a part of the collective.

The piece was a proof of concept more than a full story, so regarding his objective, while I don't think the piece shows it super clearly, this is what I am attempting with the character and would go into more depth in a longer story:
The character is self-conscious about his reclusive position in society. He is attempting to become more active in the collective of society. So he goes to the club to join the collective. This requires a defeat of his self-conscious tendencies and identity as an outsider. It requires him to dance. Though it would not solve his problems, this act would be a step in the right direction. Because regardless of what one thinks about the club, there is benefit in being able to dance with others. It proves an ability to exist in a group. But to dance, his self-conscious identity must be overcome by his desire and the infectious atmosphere of the club. If he could overcome his identity by himself, then the story would be about victory. But because he needs his identity to succumb, he must be defeated. But at the end he is still standing by the wall. He has a strength to resist the collective, but that does not bring him the defeat he desires.

Bit rambly, but this is all rough stuff at the moment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21507941
There’s a passage where the kid asks what Judge Holden is “a judge of” and (the expriest, I believe) doesn’t give any answer. McCarthy intentionally describes the judge’s background very opaquely, imo. I think he did this in order to foster some interpretations that the judge may not actually be a tangible figure, but rather an inner concept of the kid or of the gang members. I’m sure there are also other similar abstracted interpretations that one could derive from his character in the book. Just my thoughts, though. Of course, Blood Meridian is actually inspired from an autobiography, Samuel Chamberlain’s My Confessions. In which, Judge Holden is described as a real person who participated in the Glanton Gang in the 1800s. It’s unclear whether this alleged member was actually a judge, and some also “Judge Holden” to be a nickname of one of the gang members rather than any real title or name.

>>21509298
Based Jungian anon. I've never thought about this before, but I do have some experience with -STJs, and seeing as I'm an INTJ, perhaps I can help.

First off, an INFJ may have the most difficult time of all writing for an ESTJ in my opinion. For reasons I won't go into here, I believe your type represses the dominant function of the ESTJ, Te, more than any other function. Conversely, the ESTJ does the same. Ni, your and my dominant, is their most repressed function - just like the ESFJ. With that in mind it might be helpful for you to think of a sort of cloud of other types which fluidly relate to the ESTJ and which might be easier for you to comprehend the perspective of.

On the one hand you have the following:
>ESTP - alike in preference for thinking and extroverted judgement, both repress their feelings to the point of not noticing - ESTJs less so, thus more driven by an undercurrent of feeling heavily rooted in a Te-Fi "objective, generally common-sensical" morality
>ISTP - their mirror - both are driven to act quickly and efficiently with no frills. The ISTP tends more towards doing this with a stylish and idiosyncratic eye due to hyper-repressed Fi, while the ESTJ, repressing Ni is striving for insight and manifestation of a longterm vision (the 4-7 link Fi-Ni). As with all types, this will be best viewed through the lens of their 2-5 function link. Si-Ti.
>ISTJ - possibly unhelpful for you, I'm not sure. The ISTJ, sister type of the ESTJ, stuggles with Ne-Fe the relationship of Fe to the immediate big picture, and the micro-interconnections of the social sphere to the big picture. The ESTJ struggles less with this, and in fact, though not being much better at it than the ISTJ in certain regards, almost seems to pride themselves on it. I believe it is the nature of our weaker functional links to take on this aspirational nature and in so doing, orient our dominant functions to those domains. Like the ISTJ, ESTJs like dead-pan, punchy humor, generally.
>ENFP - They share all functions with an ENFP, in some ways it may be useful to imagine ENFP, ENFJ, ESTP, ESTJ as one group to get a sense for these extroverted types. Regardless, like an ENFP, they hold strong convictions and will, unlike an ENFP, try to fulfill the role of these convictions stoically, stolidly - as opposed to like a firecracker or a whip.
>INFP - I find ESTJs to be most similar to INFPs in how they enjoy company. Again, these two types share all the same preference of cognitive function in a different order, but the weaknesses of the INFP are the strengths of the ESTJ and vice versa. Beyond that, they are quite similar.
>ESFJ and ISFJ - these may be the most useful for you, being Fe-Ti users with Si-Ne preference, but I am an INTJ. Explaining Fe types to an INFJ would be comical. Fe-Se is my weakest link, thus all INTJs tend to have a lot to say about Ne-Fe via Te (which this entire post could amount to, no doubt).

(1/2)

>>21510235
Try not to think of it as a quiz. Think of the quizzes as merely a way for typists to allow themselves to be checked against the self-perception of the subject they are typing, and a way for individuals to get a handle on the system by self-typing. Since they are familiar with themselves, putting a type to self can be useful as an anchor for understanding the abstract concepts surrounding the functions. The system, at base, is a set of logically counter-balanced categorizations which represent an attempt to isolate and reduce an observed patient's processes to abstract concepts - for the purpose of gaining greater insight into the subject, and into all subjects at large. The quizzes are inherently flawed for several reasons, but the most noteworthy two are the following:

- every quiz author has a type. thus the quiz is influenced by the cognitive efficiencies and deficiencies of the quiz-maker(s)
- every test-taker has varied levels of self-observance and biases, as well as their own type - which will make it easier to comprehend the questions in the manner the test-taker intended, or harder, depending on the subject's relationship to the type of the quiz-writer

But for someone who understands the system, a gross mistype is easy to see. I generally try and type people before having them test, so I can refine my ability to type.

Not, OP, but I am the INTJ who posted before.

Homer's epic has no trace of homosexuality.

However other versions of the tale did, this had wide precedence in Greece (the romantic question is discussed in the Platonic dialogues) and it was further amplified by Rome. It may have been the case that Homer cut that element out for his rendering of the story. A faithful rendering of the Iliad as such should have no homosexuality.

That said, Madeline Miller is not pulling this out of her ass. Remember that the Iliad covers a specific length of time and backstories such as the entire history of Achilles and Patroclus are not present except through oblique references meant to jog the audience's memory. If one is to look into works concerning the history of Achilles and Patroclus, then you'll quickly run into those romantic takes.

The Gay Science. A relevant passage:

>Here is an ill-constituted man, who does not have enough spirit to rejoice, but just enough culture to know it; bored, weary, filled with self-contempt; unfortunately cheated by some inherited fortune out of the last consolation, the ‘blessings of labour’, the self-forgetfulness in the ‘daily toil’; a man who is thoroughly ashamed of his existence – perhaps he harbours a few small vices – but who cannot help indulging his taste for books he has no business reading or more intellectual companionship than he is able to assimilate, making himself vain and irritable in the process: such a thoroughly poisoned man – because for such ill-constituted men, spirit becomes poison, culture becomes poison, possessions become poison, solitude becomes poison – ultimately finds himself in a habitual condition of vengefulness, determined to avenge himself on everything …

>What do you suppose he would find absolutely necessary for seeming to himself superior to more spirited and intelligent men, for creating the enjoyment of accomplished revenge, at least in his own imagination? It is always morality that he requires, you can bet on it; always the big moral words, always this tiresome rumbling about justice, wisdom, holiness, virtue; always the Stoical demeanour (how well Stoicism hides what one does not possess!); always the mantle of sagacious silence, of affability, of gentleness, and whatever else the mantle of the idealist is called, in which the incurably self-contemptuous and also the incurably vain walk around.

>Do not misunderstand me: out of such born enemies of the spirit there arises every now and then a rare specimen of humanity who is revered by the people under the name of saint or sage; it is out of such men that there arise those moral monsters who make a noise and make history – St Augustine was one of them. Aristotle didn’t ‘hate homos’. He is ambivalent on the subject. The point is he describes it as mandated by law in some cities.
Aeschines and Demosthenes are two of the prominent legal orators of classical Athens. Good evidence for Greek social attitudes.
Xenophon didn’t ‘hate homos’ (otherwise he wouldn’t portray Socrates as attracted to boys) but he did think poorly of homosexual copulation. He helps a friend of his obtain a beloved boy in the Anabasis.
And if they all did hate homos, it just makes them even more reliable sources when they say that most Greek cities approve of pederasty.

>what if you dont know what an eatmology is
You use a dictionary with etymology or an etymological dictionary in addition to some other sort of dictionary, generally a defining dictionary.

Defining Dictionary - provides definitions
Historical Dictionary - provides definition and historical usage
Usage Dictionary - provides definition and current usage (at time of publication)
Etymological Dictionary - provides definitions and etymology

Most general dictionaries these days are a mix of each but only provide usage or etymology when deemed necessary. Usage notes will be provided for non-standard uses which are common but not worth a full entry and etymology will be provided when it helps to keep definition size down since you can flip to the entry for the word(s) it is constructed from.

>>21509764
It's very difficult to explain why I like this book as much as I do and it's one of those books that can sometimes struggle on the translations; if you can read Spanish, grab a Spanish copy over an English copy or whatever your mother tongue is.
Personally, I enjoy it a lot. The book isn't so much about self-improvement as it is about delusions of grandeur, mental health and the effects of one person in a bad way affects those around him in a negative fashion.
Obviously, the book is first and foremost about a 40 something year old man that dresses up as a knight, acts like a knight and believes he's a knight to save a woman who may not exist and if that's how you take the book, that's fine.
The themes aren't all surface level, so you can get a lot out of disecting the book in its 2 parts; the first part is more comedy focused whilst the second part is surprisingly dark.
Someone already said that part 1 slaps part 2, but for me, I prefer it the other way around; in part 2, we see not only what part 1 has done to Don Quixote but more importantly, what it does to Sancho Panza, his companion and the most level-headed character in the whole cast. I don't want to spoil the book too much, but I enjoy that during one bit of Part 2 a certain "thing" happens and Sancho tries to do a bad "thing" so that he can get out of all of this.
The book doesn't have a happy ending, but most books in this time period don't if we're being honest. I'd be happy to go into it in more depth, but I'm trying to restrain myself from spoiling this too much which you may consider arbitrary because the book is hundereds of years old.

>>21509904
The main ones are class identity, sanity and madness (in the elderly), idealism vs realism but the big one is understanding the truth and defending lies.
Some of the big parts of the Truth vs Lies is that "Seeing is believing" and there are numerous times where what Don and Sancho see are completely different with arguably the most famous being the tilting at windmills scene.
It all boils down to "Private VS Communal truth" if you will and Don's need to understand why a truth that is private can be self-destructive and his character grows to understand why a communal truth is more acceptable, but it's a little more complicated than that.
The Madness vs Sanity angle is closely connected, especially considering that Don doesn't have constant illusions around him, but only when his imagination is captivated by the books he read before he departs.
The class identity ties into self-invention a lot; the very first scene, Don essentially invents himself and it's this invention of who he is that drives everything within the story; it's akin to a child playing pretend, but in a world where there is only one player and everyone else is merely a spectator with some wishing to help/deal with Don in their own way, or play along by appeasing his imagination of himself and the world around him. As a knight, Don's "class" moreso within himself, is of a chivalrous, powerful, important man and carries himself with this haughty attitude everywhere he goes, throwing his weight around and acting superior, yet benevolent. He wants to project his powerful image to fight back a cynical, vile, vituperative world devoid of imagination and heart; he wants a piece of himself within all of those he sees around him.
The Idealism vs Realism angle is mainly explored in the two leads, the idealist Don and the realist Sancho. Sancho is the "Straight man" to Don's "Absolute fucking moron". Don isn't stupid though, but his idealist tendencies tend to struggle to fit in the world around him; where Don sees beliefs, Sancho sees Detail, Don is tall and thin, Sancho is short and squat; they're deliberate opposites in this world and their grasps on the world they live in are shown with heart and understanding, without undermining either view because after all, the world has a reason and indeed a need for idealists, but realists are just as important. Without idealism, realists become too grounded and without realism, idealists struggle to cope and understand with that which is around them.
I hope this helps, at least a bit and if anyone else wants to chime in, that'd be cool.

posts.com:
>>21510173
That's one of the big bits of the whole idealism vs realism angles.
Most, if not all people know that Don dies at the end, and denounces chivalry and idealism as a whole, but it wasn't these things that hurt him as much as it was his failure to accept realism in any capacity until he fully switched sides right before his death.
After everything, life is to be challenged and not skirted around by flights of fancy; lifes many challenges need to be tackled directly but the tragedy of the book is that what Don ultimately wanted, was to do good, to be a good person, to do good things, to teach others to do good. Realism's victory over Don is that it robs a man of his fantasy, his desire and imagination, his idealism; no man can be an idealist or realist in full because if they are, they simply aren't living a life worth living in and once Don realises that his idealism is harmful and reaches his ultimate truth that it was the only guiding light he chose to follow, we see a broken man.
Don's flaw was that he was narrow-minded and followed his creed and law to the letter, in a constant, to the detriment of himself and his others; we all know the famous line "The road to hell is paved with good intentions" and it's a massive part of the novel as a whole.
Idealism can lead to ignorance, arrogance and naïvety.
Realism can lead to apathy, nihilism and anhedonia.
Both of these killed Don on their own, because he only took one or the other and never in his entire time in the book did he take both.

>>21507191
Never put labels on your characters before you start writing, it will make the story stale and soulless. The character will not feel alive as if he is alive but rather a manifestation of the "label" itself. Every action of the character will feel like an extension of the "label" you yourself put on him. Remember all characters are human and their actions are decided by their ideas, experiences and who they truly are. The only time this does not apply is if you are writing fantasy. But even in that case I think it more often than not that you should avoid writing evil people for the sake of it.

The absurd is often defined as
>the banal shot through with atrocity

Basically absurdist literature attempts to create a kind of existential anxiety in the viewer by presenting a normal-seeming situation and highlighting instability in it

e.g.
>Godot characters are waiting, but slowly realise they have no idea how long they've been there, who they're waiting for or why
>Genet's The Maids begin as maids playing dressup and slowly lose their grasp on their identities and sense of reality

etc

>>21499970
Plotinus doctrines are scattered throughout the text. In each tractate he focuses on a specific issue but it's always written in a way that assumes you already have full background knowledge of Plotinus' overall philosophy. So the first few are going to be a hard slog until you can start piecing together what his actual views are. For this reason it's helpful to have a companion that explains Plotinus' philosophy so you get that background knowledge in order to understand each tractate better. Neoplatonism by R.T Wallis is considered one of the best.

Reading it is going to be like a puzzle where some of the early stuff will leave you baffled because it assumes you already know things elucidated in later tractates.

Pretty legitimate I think. Platos discourses are obviously not a systematic exposition of his thought, they're dialogues meant to bring up questions and propose potential answers. Neoplatonism goes a step further and fuses Platonism with mysticism

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Notes from I.1:
>The individual soul has psychological distinctions.
It is clear that passions reside in a different part of the soul than ratiocination or opinion.
>Is the soul a composite aggregate?
Is there any difference between the soul and the soul-essence? If so then it is a composite aggregate. If not then the soul would be a form and we must admit it is immortal.
>The soul is not essence.
If the soul were essence she would not be able to partake in mixture or change; she would not have fears nor passions; she would be unreceptive and unperceptive of the external and unable to suffer. Yet all this is clearly not the case.
>The soul uses the body as a tool.
How do passions from the body penetrate into the soul? If soul were separate from the body then one individual would suffer while a different one would be affected. It is philosophy (logos) that separates the soul and the body, which were originally one.
>The relation of the body and the soul before separation was a primitive one.
They were probably mingled together, with the body being the independent part and the soul its instrument; however, philosophy raises the latter to the rank of the former, and she grows independent of the body.
>There are consequence of the mixture of the soul and the body.
The body improves by participation with the soul; the soul deteriorates by association with irrationality and death.
>The soul and the body cannot be completely mixed.
They are incommensurables.
>Not all affections are common to the soul and body.
There are some which require the excitation of blood and bile and are entirely bodily. The desire for goodness on the contrary belongs entirely to the soul.
>The soul's faculties, by presence, while remaining unmoved, cause reactions in our organs that enter them into movement.
The soul and body form an aggregate where the organism's life belongs to neither fully. If corporeal emotion finds its term in the soul, the soul feels.
>Animal nature is formed by the soul.
However it is not the soul's nature in itself; it is instead the nature of the composite formed by the soul and body.
>Our higher principles concur in forming the manifold complex of human nature.
Hence the soul-body feels sensation.
>The soul only perceives the typical forms, i.e. intelligible portion, of sense objects impressed on the animal sense.
The soul receives only image of the external sensation the animal feels. Rtiocination, opinion, and thought deal exclusively with these images.
>There is a superior part of the soul, we who direct this organistaion and a lower part of the soul which is mixed with the body and is irrational.
It is this part of the soul that partakes in Nous.
>The One hovers over intelligible nature. We, on the third hypostases, partake in the World Soul which permeates all bodies.
She is indivisible and in the universe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>If she does not mix with bodies then how does she give life?
She remains individuals and gives out images of herself. These images form the faculties of the individual soul: sensation in the common part; and the forms which derive successively from each other down to the faculties of generation.
>The World Soul in creation of the individual souls is foreign to the cause of the evils man suffers.
So is the highest part of the soul, even though ratiocination belongs to it, as the latter can be the cause of great evils when mastered by the lower parts of our nature.
>Often we yield to appetite and anger, and to even lower sensation. These are the result of the soul being duped by imperfect images.
Our imagination/fantasy does not await the judgement of discursive reason. In such a case the intellect did not grasp the object itself.
>The real Man differs from the body.
"We" is taken in a double sense: either the soul with the animal body; or simply the upper part, while the body is a beast.
>the virtues consist not in wisdom but in ethical habits and austerity. They belong to the common part.
Friendships however are some referred to the common part and some to the pure Soul or inner Man.
>The superior principle, which at first seems inactive in relation to us, only begins to be active towards us when it advances as far as the middle part of our being.
To utilise the superior principle, we must direct this middle part of our being towards either the upper or lowerd worlds. This is actualisation of Aristotelian "potentiality" or Stoic "habit."
>Animal bodies can be defined according to this animating principle as human souls that have sinned.
Those animals into whose bodies no human soul have entered are produced by illumination of the World Soul.
>The common doctrine that the soul sins and undergoes punishment in Hades is not necessarily incompatible with this doctrine.
Philosophy's separation of the soul refers not only to body, but to passible accretions. The combination of the pure soul with that which experiences passions and sins is what undergoes punishment.
>The animal nature is generated when the soul descends.
As she inclines towards the body the soul sheds light onto what is below her and thereby produces an image of herself. But when she is entirely occupied in contemplating the intelligible world, this image vanishes.
>It is we, by means of the soul which makes this research. The soul considers itself.
As for the Intelligence (Nous) it is only ours insofar as the soul is intelligent; for us the higher life consists in a better thinking, when the intellect is both a part of ourselves, and a part of something superior towards which we ascend.

>If this be so, then, indeed, we may think of the soul as an immortal—if the immortal, the imperishable, must be impassive, giving out something of itself taking nothing...
Giving out necessitates diminution; diminution necessitate destruction; destruction necessitates mortality. Is the soul self-destructive? No. The soul is not giving out but instead must be growing in. It is positive abundance.
>Whatever possesses Existence is supremely free, dwelling, unchangeable, within its own peculiar nature. And can any increase bring joy, where nothing not even anything good, can accrue? What such an Existence is, it is unchangeably.
Plotinus mistakes Existence for Existing. (As he did in the above excerpt when he mistakes 'soul' for 'soul-ing'). I've written this before, but I will write it once more: I believe—in regards to the Platonic Forms—that the Principle has been abandoned in favor of the Purpose. The Is Good, is abandoned in favor of the Being Good; Permanence enters Eternity—Permanence regresses into Eternity. Be turns into Being. This Being is not an Eternity, but is(-ing) an Eternity(-ing). The present-continuous as you know it. Eternity is accruing; thus, Existing is accruing. Hence, Happinessing and Joying are accruing so long as Sadnessing and Grieving are not destroying them.

A few thoughts from tonight's reading.
I'm curious as to what the first line means in Greek
>Since Evil is here, 'haunting this world by necessary law', and it is the Soul's design to escape from Evil, we must escape hence.
I'm curious because Plotinus has already alluded to ghosts, shades, and shadows.

Any anons know which of the following Greek words are used?
>στοιχειώνω (ghost)
>συχνάζω (frequent)
>βασανίζω (linger in the mind)

Discussing civic virtues and natural law
>any participation in Ideal-Form produces some corresponding degree of Likeness to the formless Being There. And participation goes by nearness: the Soul nearer than the body, therefore closer akin, participation more fully and shows a godlike presence, almost cheating us into the delusion that in the Soul we see God entire

Participating in the Ideal-Form (goodness/virtue) materializes the forms in some sense, another shadow or piece of the Highest Good and therefore in the supreme. Plato understood the forms to be completely inaccessible except through idealism, yet Plotinus says that the form participates more directly. Yet we must be careful, for these are still mere shadows or small pieces of the ultimate Good.

>As speech is the echo of the thought in the Soul, so thought in the Soul is an echo from elsewhere: that is to say, as the uttered thought is an image of the soul-thought, so the soul-thought images a thought above itself and is the interpreter of the higher sphere.

It was understandable why one anon recommended reading Timaeus and Parmenides before this. Plotinus is echoing one of Plato's major hurdles-- that no thought is wholly original or independent. Ideas are 'discovered' rather than 'formulated' in many ways. This idea frustrated Plato, but Plotinus seems to just accept it as part of his hierarchical metaphysics.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21487869
censēre is a verb within the broad category of speaking, feeling, thinking, etc. that is, verbs that are often/normally accompanied by indirect speech. In English, though this is happening less and less, we often use 'that' to express indirect speech (e.g. "I believe THAT the money is still there.") In Latin this is normally done with infinitive verbs and accusative subjects (though you do sometimes see 'quod' being used like how English uses 'that', but this is more common in later Latin).
>Itaque deos hominibus colendos timendosque esse censuerunt
you could translate this as "Therefore they thought THAT (the) gods are to be/must be worshipped and feared by humans"
while the second one
>Dei hominibus timendi non sunt
"(the) gods must not be/are not to be feared by humans"

Please ignore the first part of my response, I wasn't fully awake yet.
"Puella" needs to be in the dative, and "aqua" needs to be the nominative if the verb is in the passive:
"Puellae aqua data est" means "The girl was given water".
"Puellae aqua datur" means "The girl is given water".

posts.name: Anonymous

Grammar is the least of your worries if you hate memorization. There's no way around it if your NL doesn't take lots of its vocabulary from your TL, like English takes from Latin.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21497612
>Are these claims about Greek true or just people blowing it out of proportion?
both, it's a scary mountain, steeper than Latin's, sure, but in reality doable, in my personal experience past a certain point even those difficulties looking back won't appear so insurmountable, there is in some sense regularity in the irregularities, especially if maybe unlike with Latin you try to learn about the phonetic phenomena that led to certain developments
e.g the third declension of Greek has many sub-variations that at first sight may make it look more complex than all of Latin's five, but once you learn what kind of phenomena led to this variety, you'll easily understand they are all or most predictable variations of a common theme, and get used to them
in many ways Greek is also easier than Latin, syntactically especially, and if you care about pronunciation, it's also easier to remember/know long and short vowels
as the other anon said, lexicon is of course a big mountain to climb and in general there isn't much you can do but read and read, but again, through a gradual approach, using readers if possible, the process can be tolerable if you aren't in a hurry

*of course there's reading and reading, I'm using a Greek-Latin bilingual edition, many sections I can work out without help or lexicon, others take more time to decipher and sometimes I have to look at the Latin; but Thucydides is considered a challenging author so I'm not complaining

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21497803
There is a certain amount you just have to learn, but there is a logic to some of it. In particular, most characters consist of a phonetic component (though it may only be an approximate homophone, and sound change makes that worse), and a radical, indicating a category of meaning. For example 媽 mǎ 'mother' is composed of 女 nǚ 'woman', the radical, and 馬 mā 'horse', the phonetic.

posts.com:
In "Mātrī 'Aemilia' nōmen est", "'Aemilia'" is attached to "nōmen", right? Thus, the sentence is not saying that "Mātrī 'Aemilia' est nōmen", but rather "Mātrī ['Aemilia' nōmen] est".

Therefore "Diēī prīmō mēnsis Iūliī 'kalendae Iūlia' nōmen est" should read as such "Diēī prīmō [mēnsis Iūliī] ['kalendae Iūlia' nōmen] est", where 'Diēī prīmō' applies itself to 'mēnsis Iūliī'.

While I'm the person you're replying to, I hardly know any Chinese, so I'm not the most qualified person to answer. Specifically, I don't know how far studying CC will realistically take me.
The core Confucian and Taoist texts are surely the baseline, and there's also lots of early poetry.
But in some form the languages was used up to 1919, and even later, so that's 2000 years of works potentially accessible to a CC reader. Sometimes the language shows up in surprising places, like in Hồ Chí Minh's poetry, or in the Japanese mythological sources. Also in coomer material, if you're looking for that.
> the grammar
The experience so far has been very different from all other languages I tried. You'll never encounter a declension table anywhere, for example.
> Unlike the other main ones discussed here, I simply do not understand the appeal unless you're some kind of weird sinophile.
The other main ones being Latin and Greek? Because compared to second tier classical languages like Hebrew and Persian, CC surely has a much more varied corpus.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So here a reading list [https://philologicalcrocodile.wordpress.com/2023/01/03/your-introductory-philology-reading-list/] by the blogger "The Philological Crocodile" (I've post his guide to reading Latin a couple of months ago) for anybody interested in about Philology. He notes how in order to do philology, you need to actually know the languages, but he believes that through these books you should get an understanding of what philology is and what philologists actually do:

> Chadwick, J. (1979). The decipherment of Linear B. Cambridge University Press.
> Feeney, D. (1998). Literature and religion at Rome: Cultures, contexts, and beliefs. Cambridge University Press.
> Fitzgerald, W. (2013). How to read a Latin poem: If you can’t read Latin yet. Oxford University Press.
> George, C. H. (2020). How dead languages work. Oxford University Press.
> Green, D. H. (2000). Language and history in the early Germanic world. Cambridge University Press.
> Irwin, R. (2007). For lust of knowing: The orientalists and their enemies. Penguin UK.
> Nietzsche We philologists [=wir philologen]
> Parsons, P. J. (2007). City of the sharp-nosed fish: Greek papyri beneath the Egyptian sand reveal a long-lost world. W&
> Puhvel, J. (1987). Comparative mythology. JHUP
> Tarrant, R. (2016). Texts, editors, and readers: Methods and problems in Latin textual criticism. Cambridge University Press.

Have any of you read any of these books, or can suggest additions or replacements?

>>21509438
If you make a small mistake you just cross it out, you use a ^ to indicate an added word that you missed. If you're constantly making mistakes and having to edit every other word, that's just a problem with spelling or organising your thoughts. Physical writing can force you t think more about the information because you have to plan more about how you're going to organise it.

These are some notes I did on an author's poems. Before starting I came up with a simple format and abbreviations. Any extra info I write in the margins. If you're constantly making errors that need editing, you probably need more practice writing, especially by hand. If you rely on spell checkers and copy-pasting all the time, you don't pick up basic writing skills. Also, if they're just notes they don't need to be perfect, an odd misspelled word won't matter. If you've ever seen notes or diaries by authors you'll see they made plenty of mistakes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21509438
Your mind is a dirty and muddy process. If you want to keep track of the 'history' of how you got to some idea you will see it in handwriting. In modern words, is a version control program with immediate update with all dorts of data (diagrams, schemes, plots,images, complex math formulas, doodles, etc) and metadata. You might find it anecdotical, but on paper you will see how were you running of a pen and yet tried to write very fast, an stain of grease will rememeber you when you were handled a sandwich, if you were in a hurry, if that you did not have an eraser, if you were writing on a table or just on your lap, maybe notes of somebody else, maybe a doodle from a friend or a random number from some person. One day's good idea caan be remembered forever as the paper where i have a weirdly folder corner.

I would say there are fields and instances where the constant exposition to processes of the mind and not elaborated products can be convenient.

On how to do the stuff in practical terms...overcome the need of clean things, that's what bothers you in the end of the day.

>>21510198
>If you're constantly making mistakes and having to edit every other word, that's just a problem with spelling or organising your thoughts. Physical writing can force you t think more about the information because you have to plan more about how you're going to organise it.
Is a good point. It's not just about learning not to make mistakes, you're training yourself to think further ahead, to plan out what you want to say before you say it, to think more carefully and become aware of the connection of each word and sentence to its neighbors. When you learn to write precisely (and, through doing so, speak more precisely), you can communicate your thoughts more powerfully. Writing with a pen is literally connecting the mind to the body, this has benefits beyond simply committing words to paper.

>We thought he should be happy. We didn’t blame her, and in fact we’d gladly forgive her if she could make Pa happy. We could see that, like us, he wasn’t. We recognized the vacant looks, the empty sighs, the frustration always visible on his face. We couldn’t be absolutely sure, because Pa didn’t talk about his feelings, but we’d pieced together, through the years, a fairly accurate portrait of him, based on little things he’d let slip.
>For instance, Pa confessed around this time that he’d been “persecuted” as a boy. Granny and Grandpa, to toughen him up, had shipped him off to Gordonstoun, a boarding school, where he was horrendously bullied. The most likely victims of Gordonstoun bullies, he said, were creative types, sensitive types, bookish types—in other words, Pa. His finest qualities were bait for the toughs. I remember him murmuring ominously: I nearly didn’t survive. How had he? Head down, clutching his teddy bear, which he still owned years later. Teddy went everywhere with Pa. It was a pitiful object, with broken arms and dangly threads, holes patched up here and there. It looked, I imagined, like Pa might have after the bullies had finished with him. Teddy expressed eloquently, better than Pa ever could, the essential loneliness of his childhood.

>>21500488
>So you are saying if I kill a person, without evil intention, it is not me who is doing it but an abstract Dharmic mechanism?
Ideally you ought to read some commentaries, namely Shankara's. The deeper message here is non-identification with the body and mind. "The one who knows and understands the activity of the gunas [the threefold interplay of the material substrate] is not deluded about the actions of the body and mind" (paraphrased from the B.G.). But the Self, Atman, is not the agent of any of this interplay, it is without a second, and therefore does not act upon anything, because there is nothing apart from it to act upon. Therefore the Self/Atman is completely without action, no one is killed by anyone, the Self does not kill. But this is the absolute height of the teaching of the B.G. On a level that is more meaningful to human beings, in this case Arjuna, there is still a choice of what to do, but the right action is indeed pre-determined by the Dharma, the Law of Manu established at the beginning of Creation (the individual is not responsible to himself, which would not make sense, but responsible to the greater order established by Manu). You would have noticed that Krishna gives more than a single reason for Arjuna to act according to his caste, and that the first I mentioned (the highest teaching) is given last as a way to eliminate Arjuna's fundamental dissatisfaction with the need to take life in general, even after he accepts the necessity of his Dharma. The "lesser reasons" are partly that it is preordained by the cosmic order (rita/dharma) and therefore intrinsically constitutes a force for good in the world, another is that death is not really the end, another is that as long as you act well, you will be rewarded whether you live or die. Moral agency is still presumed to be relevant in the case of Arjuna because he clearly has the choice of acting in accordance with his Dharma, or not doing so, the "higher teaching" is that this choice is fundamentally illusory, even though it is still necessary.
>against 2000 years of western ideas about subjectivity
You would mean approximately 500 years. "Subjectivity" is basically made up by modern philosophers, it's not found anywhere in influential thinkers like Aristotle. As for "Moral responsibility", it is omnipresent beyond western philosophy, and as stated above, is indeed found also in Hinduism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21499777
>For example, It literally removed all mentions of caste system
First off all, provide proof that caste isn't itself a perversion or a latter-day addition to the "original" Gita (if such a thing even exists). Second, explicit mention of caste was removed, yet the gunas remain. As you probably know, caste was originally an implementation of guna balances. To invoke the idea of caste without further specificity implies you reference its most recent historical implementation of "birthright" delineation. Krishna did indeed outline a caste system, but to protest Easwaran's omission thereof without mentioning the original capacity by which Krishna outlined them is uneducated at best — and disingenuous at worst. There are good reasons both for and against the inclusion of caste to the Gita without lowering the discussion to politics and "appeal to liberals." It's counterproductive to immediately frame in political context a discussion which could otherwise, and with more validity, be discussed from a more academic or spiritual standpoint.

>Redpill me on "hardboiled fiction"

Dashiell Hammett worked as a private detective for the Pinkertons. He basically invented the hardboiled detective and genre based on his experiences there.

A lot of Hammett's writing holds up very well, imo. The Maltese Falcon is terrific, as are many of his short stories. Beyond his natural writing talent, which was substantial, what made Hammett's best work so strong was the real-life experience behind it, and the note of authority and authenticity that gave to his work.

>34 “How many loaves do you have?” Jesus asked.
Jesus's pseudo-rhetorical questions are never actual questions but questions that he is asking us. When he speaks of loaves as unit of bread as amount he is making the idea of bread as distinct units that becomes important with the next answer.
>“Seven,”
Seven days of creation and 8 is the divinely perfect number with the addition of Christ.
>they replied, “and a few small fish.”
>few small fish
What this is is actually the dichotomy of those born into the faith and those who convert. Fishes are symbolically converts and bread is the symbolically here those raised in the faith so the idea here is that the Church body is sustained from itself in a way. In other words, we live by faith and are encouraged by the faith of others (Romans) rather than eating one another (Galations or Ephesians) we eat one into in a perfect sense of faith - thus why the question of loaves is addressed to us.
>35 He told the crowd to sit down on the ground.
In order to be fed by Christ we must not wander off and be willing to physically and spiritually be still for him.
>36 Then he took the seven loaves and the fish,
This is the seven end eight thing again where bread and fish may be traditionally Jew and Gentile it feels more proper to say cradle and convert and the fish is forgivenness of sin.
>and when he had given thanks,
Christ thanks God and not Himself as an act of humility.
>he broke them and gave them to the disciples, and they in turn to the people. 37 They all ate and were satisfied.
This physical miracle is to highlight the alternative physics of grace versus the law of the flesh. In the law of the flesh, food is just a limited resource you fight for, in the law of grace, faith is an unlimited resource you die for and give up.
>Afterward the disciples picked up seven basketfuls of broken pieces that were left over.
Large is the harvest but few are the laborers. The basket here is probably a subtle nod to the idea of the basket and the candle but that is too much for now.

I believed that the example of that great Reform would have blessed all the races of mankind by establishing true freedom purged of the native dangers and disorders of Republics. Therefore I deemed that you were fighting the battles of our liberty, our progress, and our civilization; and I mourn for the stake which was lost at Richmond more deeply than I rejoice over that which was saved at Waterloo.
Was he right lads?

>>21502754
I rarely say this buzzword meme phrase, but nice cope. Those restrictions were part and parcel of the metapolitical framing of the war. "All's fair in love and war" is a phrase for a reason. So is "war is politics by other means," and so is its inverse. This isn't 1685, we aren't fighting cabinet wars. All 20th century war is assymmetrical and self-consciously so. Vietnam played the possibilities of its situation perfectly and won at the strategic level fair and square.

It's no surprise that minor nations like Vietnam can't compete with industrial juggernauts like the Cold War era USA, one of the two remaining superpowers and geopolitical hegemons on the planet. For the USA to say "we only lost because we couldn't drop our thousands of nukes on every single rice farmer, because then international opinion would have turned on us and our tactical victory in Vietnam would have been geostrategically pyrrhic!!" is pathetic. Vietnam fought an incredible war using every single means at its disposal and proved that the pawns can outmaneuver the queens on the board of realpolitik. Vietnam's victory was so incredible that it's philosophically significant, it's a modern Thermopylae, Marathon, or Salamis. Who cares that the Persians burnt Athens? Does anyone even remember that? No, they remember Thermopylae, Marathon, and Salamis.

To say "we only lost because we couldn't disregard all metapolitical factors!! if we could have done total mobilization and destroyed our geopolitical hegemonic position and caused revolution on the home front, we could have had more tanks than you!! you had a worse K:D ratio!!!" is childish and shows a lack of understanding of war. War is the ultimate anti-cope arena, all copes go directly in the trash. Victory is victory. Vietnam won.

Difference and Repetition is the most relevant metaphysics treatise of our time imo, but I dont see it ever being recognised as such because people either 1) have the bias of "le wacky philosopher" because they only read (a few pages of) capitalism and schizophrenia, or, 2) only read and like capitalism and schizophrenia and stay there because DR makes their brain hurt too much (which is normal), but since they dont read the early work, they keep spreading the wacky image

>>21504468
>just new age gibberish at its core.
I don't think so. Miya was the only exercise in digital art truly native to the platform that has been executed thus far. Utilizing anonymity, malleability of persona to form your own extremist mini-cult, stylized around an isolatory, digital hikikomori lifestyle was novel, and still is. The philosophical inflection and accelerationism are somewhat sidelined by this. Miya has had a large, if unnoticed and uncredited effect on the online space -- similar to BAP: their influence is much softer and unconsciously memetic than direct continuities.

No-one has really filled the hole Miya has left. I have hopes for Remilia in terms of elevating digital interfacing for the interested few, but it is true that C. Fang has much less potency overall than Miya.

I remember I just got out of a kinokuniya in NYC and sat across a park with my newly purchased collection of Mishima books. It was a good feeling as this was my first time in the big city and I felt quite ambitious and invigorated, doubly so as I began to remember the passion of Mishima works. As I sat there admiring the cover of the temple of golden pavilion, I saw a cute Asian girl from across another bench looking at me book in hand. I never had much luck with women because I lacked experience and confidence, after reading sun and steel I had gotten quite fit and fairly well groomed and dressed, so this was my first opportunity ever. The second time she turned we locked eyes and I shyly looked away. I decided it would be pathetic of me to not at least try so I struck a conversation and we talked about each other’s books. I began to describe in great detail about the life of Mishima and she was struck with great shock but luckily this manifested as an interest so she seemed to enjoy the conversation and so did I. We decided to walk around the city and she showed me her campus and some other cool scenic spots. She said it was getting late and I didn’t want to make it awkward so I volunteered to leave. We embraced each other, hugging and saying our goodbyes. Looking back had I been more confident I would’ve really sealed the deal probably stayed the night with her but I was too nervous. If you’re reading this Lynn, thank you for making me feel not disgusted with myself for once, thank you for bearing with my lengthy explanations. While I did enjoy some of the ideological discussions presented, I still think Crime and Punishment is Dosto's best work by far. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21502986
>identify any topic or subject of interest that you like
>research its history
>discover that its modern iteration was in all likelihood built on the work of Anglos
For example my interest is in Platonism and what you discover when you look at translations and scholarship on Platonism and Platonic revival is that (autistic) Anglos were the powerhouses behind it.
Another thing worth mentioning is that England has a very rich history but each period is very different from the rest. For example, Anglo-Saxon England is cool but not especially interesting IMO. Medieval England is captivating because of its complexity and activity - the wars in France and the crusades are super cool. If you like knights, you should read up on the reign of Richard the Lionheart for sure. He's like the quintessential knightly prince. After the medieval period, personally I find English history really boring up until the modern period when suddenly shit hits the fan every which way. Victorian era to 1930 is peak history kino.
IMO one of the best things about England is reading about the cultural, philosophical etc work that was being done. English philosophy is shit but on the margins of the discipline the English did lots of really awesome shit, like translating rare ancient texts and such.
