I hate this website and hate captcha

So I'm gonna attempt to post this a few times and hopefully it works

For old times sake. Sorry for reddit spacing. Grad student of phil. Force of habit to punctuate.

But fulcanelli is legit. His writings at least. Persona may be imaginary.

Evola is alright. Jung is alright too. More similar than you'd think.

If you want some dope modern scholarship which is free online then look for aaron cheak's circumambulating the alchemical tradition article which iirc is available on the rubedo press website -- it is the first chapter of one of the best recent english books on the subject

If you want to read about alchemy historically then pick up the alchemy reader perhaps. Then delve into hermetica. Copenhaver has best notes. Scott has translation and original. Mead has a mason theosophy inspired history and translation called thrice greatest hermes. There's some cheaper ones without notes but I'd recommend the more scholarly ones unless you are already versed on myth magic gnosticism neoplatonism and paganism and so on in western antiquity.

Best secondary work on Hermes is Egyptian Hermes. Tour de force. Vindicates claims of prechristian egyptian origin

Best secondary work on esotericism generally is Western Esotericism: A Guide for the Perplexed by Wouter Hanegraaf then maybe download the dictionary on gnosis and esotericism of his and read entries on magic and occult and esoteric and neoplatonism and gnosticism and hermeticism and platonism and paganism and neopaganism and mysticism and masonry and rosicrucianism and renaissance and art of memory and noesis and gnosis and such

Very academic but summarizes current state of field

PS: If you like Guenon/Evola/Jung/Crowley check out Eliade and Culianu! Shamanism is a classic by former in addition to him creating religious studies generally and has curious pseudo-nietzscheanism and everything translated from latter is pure fire, straight bangers, etc. -- I also think all esotericists should consider reading Strauss wrt esotericism in philosophy proper. I do not completely agree but am sympathetic.

PPS: Once you've read all this, check out Occult Mind: Magic in Theory and Practice if you wanna continue the academic side of things... allusive and elusive but possibly my favorite book I read the year before last...

>Alchemy changes the character of things, and raises them up into higher states of existence. To exercise this power, not mere mechanical labour, but artistic skill is required.

—Franz Hartmann

>“To grasp the invisible elements; to attract them by their material correspondences; to control, purify, and transform them by the living power of the Spirit—this is true alchemy.

>As the fowl produces a chicken with wings and legs out of the small microcosm contained in the shell of an egg, so the arcana of Nature are ripened by the processes of alchemy. Natural alchemy causes the pear to ripen, and produces grapes on a vine. Natural alchemy separates the useful elements from the food that is put into the stomach, transforms it into chyle and blood, into muscles and bones, and rejects that which is useless. A physician who knows nothing of alchemy can only be a servant of Nature, however well he may be versed in the science of external things; but the alchemist is her lord. If the physician cannot infuse vitality into decaying parts, he cannot effect a cure, but must wait until Nature accomplishes the task; but he who can guide the power of life can guide and command Nature.”

— Franz Hartmann,The Life of Paracelsus

>First there should be the invocation of God, flowing from the depth of a pure and sincere heart, and a conscience which should be free from all ambition, hypocrisy and vice, as also from all cognate faults, such as arrogance, boldness, pride, luxury, worldly vanity, oppression of the poor, and similar iniquities which should all be rooted out of the heart—that when a man appears before the Throne of Grace, to regain the health of his body, he may come with a conscience weeded of all tares, and be changed into a pure temple of God cleansed of all that defiles.“

— Basil Valentine

Although many of the traditional alchemists practiced both laboratory experiments as well as spiritual exercises, most modern so-called alchemists engage mostly with the latter. This has diluted the term somewhat and now there is much new age alchemy bullshit on the market but at the same time this is nothing new. Spirituality was always an integral part of such. Also, hermeticism as an esoteric philosophy is much broader than the mere practice of alchemy. Jung used alchemical principles to develop his theories of individuation and create what is now called active imagination. This latter practice he believed was more helpful and healing to the world than all his psychological theories combined -- provided people actually practice it. Which admittedly he worried was more dangerous and difficult. People like Lull also used techniques similar to active imagination to create vast memory palaces and turn themselves into what is almost like, if you'll pardon my Dune reference, a human mentat, or walking encyclopedia.

posts.com:
What is alchemy? Half a century ago there was little doubt in the West. It was a superstition among ignorant ancients that, by certain manipulations, base metals could be turned into gold.

Then, when Freudian and Jungian ideas began to circulate in Europe, a new, enlightened view of alchemy became fashionable. The alchemists were psychoanalysing themselves. They were sublimating and calcining their own subconscious. Their real aim was not to make gold but to make a non-aberrated man.

As pursuits of this kind in the Middle Ages overlapped territory which the Church held to be its own, the alchemists had been obliged to conceal what they were really doing behind an apparently lunatic attempt to turn lead into gold.

Even for the new psychological avant-garde this explanation was not entirely satisfactory, because it was well known that even in the 20th century highly intelligent men in Fez, Cracow, Damascus, Paris and London were currently engaged in attempts to make perfectly tangible yellow gold. They had given up charcoal furnaces and were using Calor gas, but they were manifestly doing something with pots and pans, and not with Egos and Ids.

Perhaps all external ideas about the nature of alchemy could be put into four views, separately or in combination:

First View: It is possible to transmute one element into another. One such transmutation is lead or iron into gold. From some unimaginable antiquity, a mighty secret has been handed down which shows how to do this. It is the most closely kept secret in human history.

Second View: Alchemy is the science of purifying man’s inner nature and arriving at a non-aberrated individual. Such an individual would have, by comparison with ordinary men, certain advanced powers. For political reasons, this exercise had to be concealed in a pseudo-science of metal refining to which the Church would have no reason to object.

Third View: Metals CAN be transmuted. Lead CAN be turned into gold. An alchemist knows how to do this, and also knows a greater secret. If he is in a certain relation to the crucible in which the process happens, a comparable transmutation takes place in his own common presence. As lead turns into gold in the crucible, the operator’s mind is transformed. He is subjected to something like nuclear radiation. Also, certain chemical by-products in the crucible are capable of being stored and used to either make more gold or to transform other men. Hence legends of “The Sly Man’s Pill” and the Elixir which Saint-Germain is supposed to have offered Casanova when he was dying.

Fourth View: An alchemist is a man who knows an immensely powerful method of cleaning the Augean stable of his own subconscious mind. Pushed far enough, this process gives rise to a true soul-body inholding the properties of a different order of things. If this soul-body is directed on the base metals in a certain way (projection), it will accomplish a comparable transmutation in inorganic matter.

>Since all things are God, in all things thou seest just so much of God as thy capacity affordeth thee.
Aleister Crowley, The Vision and the Voice: With Commentary and Other Papers (Equinox IV:2)

But it so happens that everything on this planet is, ultimately, irrational; there is not, and cannot be, any reason for the causal connexion of things, if only because our use of the word "reason" already implies the idea of causal connexion. But, even if we avoid this fundamental difficulty, Hume said that causal connexion was not merely unprovable, but unthinkable; and, in shallower waters still, one cannot assign a true reason why water should flow down hill, or sugar taste sweet in the mouth. Attempts to explain these simple matters always progress into a learned lucidity, and on further analysis retire to a remote stronghold where every thing is irrational and unthinkable.

If you cut off a man's head, he dies. Why? Because it kills him. That is really the whole answer. Learned excursions into anatomy and physiology only beg the question; it does not explain why the heart is necessary to life to say that it is a vital organ. Yet that is exactly what is done, the trick that is played on every inquiring mind. Why cannot I see in the dark? Because light is necessary to sight. No confusion of that issue by talk of rods and cones, and optical centres, and foci, and lenses, and vibrations is very different to Edwin Arthwait's treatment of the long-suffering English language.

Knowledge is really confined to experience. The laws of Nature are, as Kant said, the laws of our minds, and, as Huxley said, the generalization of observed facts.

It is, therefore, no argument against ceremonial magic to say that it is "absurd" to try to raise a thunderstorm by beating a drum; it is not even fair to say that you have tried the experiment, found it would not work, and so perceived it to be "impossible." You might as well claim that, as you had taken paint and canvas, and not produced a Rembrandt, it was evident that the pictures attributed to his painting were really produced in quite a different way.

You do not see why the skull of a parricide should help you to raise a dead man, as you do not see why the mercury in a thermometer should rise and fall, though you elaborately pretend that you do; and you could not raise a dead man by the aid of the skull of a parricide, just as you could not play the violin like Kreisler; though in the latter case you might modestly add that you thought you could learn.

This is not the special pleading of a professed magician; it boils down to the advice not to judge subjects of which you are perfectly ignorant, and is to be found, stated in clearer and lovelier language, in the Essays of Thomas Henry Huxley.

>Aleister Crowley

Oh and also Martinism can't be 'Catholic' given that it's heavily rooted in Freemasonry

Pasqually's system was some kind of proto-Scottish Rite thing where the candidate denounces normal masonry in favour of """real""" masonry, while Saint-Martin I think initially didn't tie it to a masonic structure but was nonetheless heavily involved in masonry

At the time, masons were under latae sententia excommunication from the Church, i.e. if you became a mason you were automatically kicked out, no need for a Bishop to find out or something. So none of these guys were Catholics.

Since 1983 it's been less clear what actually happens but at the very least its a grave sin (read: no sacraments) and possibly the excommunication might still be in effect

There are people online arguing that Martinist groups constitute some kind of basically-orthodox way of doing Catholic occultism but they clearly don't. If you want to do that just become a Lutheran or something where most of the Masonic/Rosicrucian stuff developed anyway, it's really not compatible with Catholicism imo

The Unknown God or Agnostos Theos (Ancient Greek: Ἄγνωστος Θεός) is a theory by Eduard Norden first published in 1913 that proposes, based on the Christian Apostle Paul's Areopagus speech in Acts 17:23, that in addition to the twelve main gods and the innumerable lesser deities, ancient Greeks worshipped a deity they called "Agnostos Theos"; that is: "Unknown God", which Norden called "Un-Greek". In Athens, there was a temple specifically dedicated to that god and very often Athenians would swear "in the name of the Unknown God" (Νὴ τὸν Ἄγνωστον, Nē ton Agnōston). Apollodorus,[citation needed] Philostratus and Pausanias wrote about the Unknown God as well.

According to the book of Acts, contained in the Christian New Testament, when the Apostle Paul visited Athens, he saw an altar with an inscription dedicated to that god (possibly connected to the Cylonian affair), and, when invited to speak to the Athenian elite at the Areopagus, gave the following speech:

22Paul stood in the middle of the Areopagus, and said, "You men of Athens, I perceive that you are very religious in all things. 23For as I passed along, and observed the objects of your worship, I found also an altar with this inscription: 'TO AN UNKNOWN GOD.' What therefore you worship in ignorance, this I announce to you. 24The God who made the world and all things in it, he, being Lord of heaven and earth, doesn't dwell in temples made with hands, 25neither is he served by men's hands, as though he needed anything, seeing he himself gives to all life and breath, and all things. 26He made from one blood every nation of men to dwell on all the surface of the earth, having determined appointed seasons, and the boundaries of their dwellings, 27that they should seek the Lord, if perhaps they might reach out for him and find him, though he is not far from each one of us. 28'For in him we live, and move, and have our being.' As some of your own poets have said, 'For we are also his offspring.' 29Being then the offspring of God, we ought not to think that the Divine Nature is like gold, or silver, or stone, engraved by art and design of man. 30The times of ignorance therefore God overlooked. But now he commands that all people everywhere should repent, 31because he has appointed a day in which he will judge the world in righteousness by the man whom he has ordained; of which he has given assurance to all men, in that he has raised him from the dead."

—Acts 17:22-31

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21509027
Because the Jewish God could not be named, it is possible that Paul's Athenian listeners would have considered his God to be "the unknown god par excellence". His listeners may also have understood the introduction of a new god by allusions to Aeschylus' The Eumenides; the irony would have been that just as the Eumenides were not new gods at all but the Furies in a new form, so was the Christian God not a new god but rather the god the Greeks already worshipped as the Unknown God. His audience would also have recognized the quotes in verse 28 as coming from Epimenides and Aratus, respectively.

In dealing with a flock of any kind, the shepherd or cowherd, or the keeper of horses or any such animals, will never attempt to look after it until he has first applied to each group of animals the appropriate purge—which is to separate the sound from the unsound, and the well-bred from the ill-bred, and to send off the latter to other herds, while keeping the former under his own care; for he reckons that his labor would be fruitless and unending if it were spent on bodies and souls which nature and ill-nurture have combined to ruin, and which themselves bring ruin on a stock that is sound and clean both in habit and in body,—whatever the class of beast,—unless a thorough purge be made in the existing herd. This is a matter of minor importance in the case of other animals, and deserves mention only by way of illustration; but in the case of man it is of the highest importance for the lawgiver to search out and to declare what is proper for each class both as regards purging out and all other modes of treatment. For instance, in respect of civic purgings, this would be the way of it.

>Of the many possible modes of purging, some are milder, some more severe; those that are severest and best a lawgiver who was also a despot might be able to effect, but a lawgiver without despotic power might be well content if, in establishing a new polity and laws, he could effect even the mildest of purgations. The best purge is painful, like all medicines of a drastic nature,—the purge which hales to punishments by means of justice linked with vengeance, crowning the vengeance with exile or death: it, as a rule, clears out the greatest criminals when they are incurable and cause serious damage to the State. A milder form of purge is one of the following kind:—when, owing to scarcity of food, people are in want, and display a readiness to follow their leaders in an attack on the property of the wealthy,—then the lawgiver, regarding all such as a plague inherent in the body politic, and in the friendliest possible way, will say they should be (as it will be tactfully put) "transferred to a colony."

posts.name: First Flash Fiction
posts.sub: I've always been a firm believer, that nothing last forever
posts.com:
when it's minus 40 or when eating ginger drop cookies: revel.
Turning compost. I saw cat.
Observing actions—not focused—hunter—catching lightning bugs in the summer—looking perplexed—lost in thoughts.
Thoughts on why the soil is barren. Soil crafted with labor, with much well welcomed help from all in the grand cycle.
With the last toss of decayed plant matter, glimmers caught my eye. Soon the whole sky was filled with pinks and purples.
Whatever her brain is capable of: I know she can't see this great beauty.

I'll let William Hazlitt do the talking.

>"Satan is the most heroic subject that ever was chosen for a poem, and the execution is as perfect as the design is lofty. The sense of his punishment seems lost in the magnitude of it; the fierceness of tormenting flames is qualified and made innoxious by the greater fierceness of his pride; the loss of infinite happiness to himself is compensated in thought, by the power of inflicting infinite misery on others. Yet Satan is not the principle of malignity, or of the abstract love of evil, but of the abstract love of power, of pride, of self-will personified, to which last principle all other good and evil, and even his own, are subordinate. From this principle he never flinches. His thoughts burn like a hell within him; but the power of thought holds dominion in his mind over every other consideration."

posts.name: Anonymous

I do love Hazlitt, and that's a cool quote -- I'll have to check it out. Is there a discrepancy, here, though, between Satan as being heroic, vs as being a heroic subject?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21506840
>between Satan as being heroic, vs as being a heroic subject
If I get your meaning right, yeah, I would say so. Hazlitt compares him to Homer's Achilles, Prometheus, and Hesiod's Titans after the quote in order to illustrate Satan's literary progeny. He's a hero in the Greek tragedian sense, and not really in the comic book sense the word holds nowadays.
>I prefer Lewis's take from "An introduction to paradise lost"
Lewis's introduction was very eloquent and perceptive stuff, but I think he was effectively answered by William Empson in his book, "Milton's God". I personally think Paradise Lost is far too multidimensional and contains way too many conflicting discourses (such as the tension between Satan and the Bard narrator, for instance) for it not to denote or demand Romantic interpretations that go beyond C.S. Lewis's "Mere Christianity" or moralistic reading of Satan's purpose in the text. I disagree most characteristically with him when he makes Satan an analogue to Iago rather than to Hamlet, who is his most direct predecessor in every sense.

I have been reading these books recently. I like the way Erikson composes his sentences but I detest his approach to characters. Every character is either some immortal demigod or an elite, world-weary soldier/warlock/assassin who stops every five minutes to ponder the futility of life. Every other character is a woman or a negro, which means nothing in Eriksons world but still chafes because he never fails to describe them in case you were thinking about imagining them as white. I like that he doesn't try to do a Sanderson and produce some kind of autistic magic scheme that is really just marvel super powers but despite that the magic here feels way too powerful to be this commonplace. Characters appear that can level continents with their mind and yet somehow the world keeps spinning despite many of these characters being literally insane.

Also for a fantasy novel it never really takes a moment to revel in the fantastical. Every five seconds somebody is being burned alive or decapitated or being tossed into a dimension of eternal torment. It's like warhammer 40k but everyone is a redditor armed with a crossbow and knives.

>>21504597
Erikson's world is insane in a good sense, wide like the ocean and filled with so much over-the-top epicity that you can make several ttrpg settings out of it without losing charm. Sadly, so far extends the geniality of Malazan: Alongside a pretty tiny group of genuinely strong and complex characters we have a flood of basic archetypes carrying the plot forwad and leaving no trace besides two or three iconic moments and a pool of blood. Names and faces come and go, easily forgotten not because the story is that massive but because there is no reason for their existence but plot.

Worse than that, despite compromising himself with the Grimdark Erikson has to be, so far, the most preachy, self-righteous modern author I ever had the displeasure to meet, going into senseless, clumsy tangents that serve no purpose besides confirming him as a good, modern, western humanist like literally everyone else in the scene. I can accept an author that preaches, but one that believes himself revolutionary while spouting the most baseline, unjustified modern nonsense is just painful to deal with. I love Chain of Dogs and Malazan as a setting (and only a setting), but you have to be mad to think this in any way or form surpasses Tolkien.

>>21503025
There's a couple of related purposes to the math/science part of the program. Otoh, a bunch of these readings go hand in hand with laboratory practicums (dissecting a heart reading Harvey, chemistry experiments with Lavoisier, weight and balance experiments with Archimedes and Pascal, etc), where part of the point is to learn how science developed by seeing for ourselves whether the experiments bear out the observations and conclusions of various thinkers. But in addition, since here is some broad cultural agreement on the notion of modernity being a kind of crisis, reading older workks of math and science offer an opportunity to grapple with their development and increasingly important role in culture and politics. For example, Vieta is read in sequence with some equations by Diophantus and followed up with Descartes' Geometrie to see how arithmetic comes to treat geometrical quantities and magnitudes. This is really another way of being able to see concretely what we gain and lose by formulating algebra. Similarly, we go through Ptolemy, Copernicus, Galileo, and Kepler to investigate what was involved in trying to establish the order of the solar system.

They probably develop some of the requisites for them along the way. They read some texts in ancient geometry and arithmetic (like Euclid's Elements, Nicomachus' Arithmetic), some early modern algebra and geometry works (like Vieta's Introduction to the Analytical Art and Descartes' Geometry), so even if they don't start knowing everything necessary, they should along the way be able to "catch up" by becoming acquainted with the historical predecessors for each one.
As mentioned by one of their students in this post >>21504232 , they do go through exercises and lab practices along with each one of the math and scientific texts they read, so they don't really get exactly the same experience a person who's got nothing but those original texts would get from reading them all by themselves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21509012
>Do they even have the requisite knowledge to understand them?
Yes. Students have to pass an algebra exam sophomore year in order to be allowed to continue any further in the program. They can take as many times as they want until they pass, but if they don't pass by the end of the year, they're out; math the first two years is mostly geometry and some trig (Euclid, Ptolemy, Apollonius), culminating in Diophantine equations, Vieta, and Descartes' algebra, so the demand is that the students show they're prepared to take on the math subsequent, or at least be willing to put the effort in reviewing. Junior year starts off with Galileo for a week or two in math (covered simultaneously for a longer period in lab), and we move almost immediately into several of Leibniz's papers setting out his differential calculus via a manual with lots of notes translating the ideas for modern students. The manual also functions as a primer for the kind of calculus that we see in the rest of the Junior and Senior year math and lab authors. As far as math goes (and I was never skilled at it), Maxwell and Einstein are shockingly straightforward. Maxwell practically holds your hand from paper to paper showing how and why we start and end where we do, and Einstein just uses some of Maxwell's equations.

I haven't read the later version, but I have read the original and I have a rough understanding of what was done in the following version. The later version supposedly gets rid of the nationalist sentiment, the ideals of glory and courage in the face of danger, et cetera which make the original stand apart from other first-hand accounts of modern warfare—see the last ~20 pages of the original translation for the best example of this. Junger almost certainly edited these portions or got rid of them to keep the book in print, as the appetite for such writing was not exactly great after WW2, but in doing so, he reduces Storm of Steel to yet another run-of-the-mill memoir with the tired cliche of "war bad". You might as well read any other infantryman's story from the past 120 years if this part of Junger's book is left out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Creighton translation is less polished but translates a version closer to Junger's original intent with the novel in the 1920s when he was still involved with Freikorps culture and hoping for a national revolution. His assistant who wrote the book on these movements got mad at him for his later edits because he felt they were erasing history, because Junger was putting the edits in his collected works as the authoritative versions. But the truth is Junger edited and changed works a lot and it wasn't a singular later edit, it was just decades of changed perspective. His later style is much more self-conscious and aestheticizing than his earlier style, I think he saw the earlier style as less "timeless" mainly, more infected by the contingency of contemporary events. But for people who read Junger for a window into those events and that contingency, it's kind of annoying to know you're reading a version he edited in his 60s. Still, the differences are not extreme and you can find comparisons between them online. Sometimes the newer editions even have more content.

There is a German critical edition that retains all the different versions and changes overlapping with one another so you can read everything.

I prefer Creighton personally.

So thing is as follows. Jünger was a huge nationalist and wanted to help with the effort of the national revolution. This revolution didn't happen though. They were not his kind of nationalists. Jünger was suspicious of them from the get go. He though they were bad eggs and up to no good. So he defused the book, toned it down a few notches. Pulled its teeth. All with the intent to prevent the nazis from instrumentalizing and exploiting his work for their cause. After the war, he never changed the book back to the way it was intended when he first wrote it. That is why the 1929 version is the best and most true version of the book.

>>21509139
I think what the other anon is trying to say is that he gives the impression of a try hard because JFW doesn't actually believe in, at least in his work, actualising the romantic notion of sincerity, when there is no authenticity all we really have is a sort of anal rationalism, I think JFW was actually conscious of this and the footnotes are a sort of interesting mishmash between the aesthetic of American cinematic end credits and a critique of the rationalist academic explanatory thing. I have the same impression as you, that JFW’s writing has a MFA flavour to it, but for different reasons, I think the best parts of the novel are the moments when he gives into his desires, rather than shackling them in order to conform to an intellectual narrative, when he gives himself a little freedom, often this manifests through his humour. I can appreciate how every facet of the plot has a underlying meaning, the fact that the world is split into three poles, the tennis academy, the desert steppe, and the addiction clinic, is probably emblematic of the opposing philosophies of social order that underpin society itself, a sort of Aristotelian betterment through competitive struggle vs a sort of social contract based upon habilitating an innate sinfulness or hedonistic tendency and then a sort of security state thing, but it also seem’s like a lot of the setting is from his own life, so idk how ‘deep’ it really is, maybe it is all sort of facile posturing that an MFA spat out in order to please his supposed peers.

It turns into shit by the end of the second chapter. You can almost see Pynchon struggling to make the chapters coherent. The narrative returns are greatly diminished by this point and the sentences are way, way less fluid, even taking into consideration the stylistic change.
The Gotinga chapters in particular were painful to read as Pynchon wrestles with his aging erudition, the introduction of poorly developed secondary characters(even by his standards) and a drop in quality of the prose.
This could be intentional, of course, but that's unlikely because the rest of the book is almost as good as the first chapters. I'm not lambasting his writing just pointing out his limitations when trying to continue a story he started.

I'm down with that notion. Is there anything separating this perceived incoherence with actual incoherence? Have you in all earnestness given this newer work the same level of intellectual scrutiny that you gave the earlier ones?

I'm not speaking in an accusatory way, mind, but in a projecting way. I found that I most enjoyed Pynchon when I was in school, because I would choose to write essays on his work which demanded a level of intellectual rigor. As an adult who doesn't have to write papers on what I'm reading, I tend to find that his newer stuff (or new to me stuff) washes over me like a wave, because I don't have the same investment.

I guess the larger question I have is: is his work actually rewarding to people who aren't forcing themselves to pore over it for school, or is he delusionally upheld by grad school students who feel smart that he's the only remaining American author who takes any decoding?

Again, I'm swiping at myself here, not you.

I've read every Pynchon novel except Bleeding Edge, and I think AtD is pretty bad—certainly much worse than GR and M&D. While those novels aren't exactly "coherent," they do hold together thematically and stylistically, while AtD does not. But the real problem with AtD is that even the quality of the prose is extremely inconsistent, to the point that it often reads like a mediocre imitation of a real Pynchon novel. I do think there's a great 500-700 page novel trapped inside the 1,200 page novel Pynchon actually wrote.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21509145
If you subscribe to Aristotle then even tragedies are life-affirming in a way as tried and tested through the centuries they still are a direct link to the nerve centre of human experience. But other than tragedies, the last book Time Regained in Proust’s In Search of Lost Time and Joyce’s Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man and Ulysses are some of the most unambiguously life-affirming books I’ve read. It’s also on the OP chart but The Book of Ebenezer Le Page is wonderful and truly underrated. It does conform more with Aristotle’s model though since it’s certainly not bereft of tragedy, but of course that’s precisely what makes it life-affirming. Really the Greeks had it all figured out.

Foreigner is a bit weak at times. The plot is basically one human guy on the Planet GigaNigga learning to a) cope with a literally alien way of life and b) become the lynchpin of human-alien relations. You can tell he's pretty stressed.
IMHO Cherryh's best stuff is Chanur (space merchant lionesses!), Cyteen (if you replace the smartest person in the universe with a clone raised from infancy, can you truly control them?) And Downbelow Station (political intrigues threaten a giant space station hovering above a resource-rich planet. Humans and gentle apelike aliens are both in grave danger). The latter haunted my sleep for several days, the suspense of the station just a few steel plates removed from open space really got at me.

>>21502873
Fuck yes to Bujold. I’ve reread her books so many times. Vorkosigan’s my favorite, but Penric & Desdemona is fun as heck, and World of the Five Gods is pretty singular. (Anon’s Chalion.)
I also love Joan D. Vinge. The Snow Queen, The Summer Queen and World’s End have been a few of my favorite books since i was a kid, and her Cat books grew on me over the years.
Cherryh is definitely top of the line. I agree 100% with Cyteen, Regenesis (Cy’s sequel,) and Downbelow Station.
James Tiptree Jr’s written some unforgettable short stories that are pretty indescribable. Tepper’s Grass makes you shiver, Elizabeth Moon’s Remnant Population is probably the single most entertaining story I’ve read, on a personal tongue-in-cheek level. I loved Nancy Kress’s Sleepless series, Patricia Wrede, Madeline L’Engle, Mercedes Lackey, Diane Duane, Lynn Flewelling, Robin Hobb and Dianna Wynne Jones in the kids’ books vein are old classics, though that’s moving towards fantasy. There are a bunch more hidden giants, too. Shelley for example, since we don’t really think of her books as science fiction, nowadays.
In trying recent titles, Planetfall and Atlas Alone by Newman were pretty interesting for a new author’s yield— they felt like kid slush at first, but the psychological warping in the minds of the characters felt very vivid and provoked interesting and colorful reflections on their surroundings that I ended up really warming to. I loved the house of reclaimed waste. That idea will stick with me for a long time.

Am I the only one, who only likes fantasy books with a good ending a Mary Sue characters, which are hidden as vulnurable while being "killed" and somehow reborn?

I think the worst thing in a fantasy book is if you have a character you love who then just dies. For example in Sanderson's Mistborne was a famous character that died and that was it about him. Even when I finished the series I was still pissed that a character I liked died forever. I deliberately chose Sanderson and not GRRM as an example of "killing your favorite character", because Sanderson rather tries to keep his characters alive instead of GRRM's rule of "If my characters breathe, they need to die and shart and fart".

Sure, if a series ends, "all characters die in the end", but when I read a book, I want to be certain that those characters I like will be there all the time. That's why I read fantasy books, because I want a story that is making me want to immerse myself in the world.
If I want to see death and destruction that succeeded, or books with no happy ending or no emotional ending, I could just go outside or read scientific books.

>>21503619
The problem with death in modern fiction is that it is generally used as a crutch, an easy way to score drama points with cheap emotional tricks or to write yourself out of a sticky situation because you forgot what you wanted to do with a character. In other words, it's the first and last resort of bad writers who don't know how to write endings, so they just kill the person before their story is finished and shift focus to a new character that they can kill before their story is finished and shift focus to a new character...ad infinitum to avoid ever having to write the most important part of a story: the conclusion.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21503759
Joseph W. Campbell, Jr. is famous for writing Who Goes There? (Frozen Hell) in 1939 which you might recognize as the direct inspiration for John Carpenter's 1982 movie "The Thing"
Wayne Barlowe's Expedition has a complete alien ecosystem designed in ways genuinely biologically alien to typical human conceptions, and he also wrote God's Demon and The Heart of Hell, which aside from advancing the classical depiction of the Hell of Dante's Inferno into increasingly terrifying and revolting forms, also creates a Hell beneath Hell (the pit of Abaddon) that is so horrific and inscrutable even the demons who run Hell run in fear from it.
Michael Crichton's Congo, and Eaters of the Dead, while not bearing any trace of the supernatural, do bear similar themes to Lovecraft's earlier work outside the Cthulhu mythos, particularly involving racial degeneration and miscegenation.
Robert E. Howard's Conan the Barbarian, Solomon Kane, and Kull the Conqueror have Lovecraftian elements, but they are typically overcome with a minimum of distress and effort, rather than there being any question of the heroes' success.
C.S. Lewis' Space Trilogy is functionally Lovecraftian in its portrayal of alien races and their cultures as well as the entities that comprise Christian veneration, but of course from the completely opposite perspective that these supernatural entities generally constitute a very wholesome and generous treatment of humans - with the exception of the bad ones, who make Lovecraftian gods look quite nice and friendly by comparison, and the humans themselves, who are worse.

>>21506512
John Carpenter's The Thing is based off a 1939 wierd fiction story called Who Goes There? by Joseph W. Campbell, Jr.
Most of John Carpenter's films amount to "weird fiction" in cinematic form, at least on a fundamental basis. It's a very broad genre, and can include everything from conventional sword and sorcery and sci-fi to ghost stories and fairy tales, it's just that "weird fiction" typically refers to a fast-paced and action-packed style associated with pulp magazines of the era.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21508106
You sit down with your ideas and fill up a few dozen pages with situations which demonstrate them, then you go through those pages and find a common thread. If you are a plot fag (you sort of sound like it) then you just fill up a few dozen pages with all your ideas and find that common thread, no need for figuring out situations which demonstrate the idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21508106
I am not a writefag, but if my experience with visual art has taught me anything, you need to just start. Writing and drawing are putting your thoughts on paper, and once you have enough down you can begin to crystallize and refine. Trying to keep it all in your head is worthless and takes up your memory, so you can't properly free your mind into creating/writing/drawing more. A lot of problems literally solve themselves or turn out to not exist when you just begin to act, rather than think.

It is also the only way you learn. Accept that some of your early work is terrible - but don't get discourage and think that just because the result was bad that the effort must've been futile. Being bad at something is the first step towards being good at it. It helps to fail fast, so don't try to make massive-scale work the first thing - small quick daily paintings were good in art, and I figure short stories might be the /lit/ equivalent. Something you can finish kinda fast, see how it came out, and learn from for the next time.

The anxiety of starting doesn't ever really go away, but it gets easier to overcome as you start getting results in terms of finished work - even if it isn't very good. Having finished something - anything - is a pretty good dopamine boost that you'll be motivated to seek out again. That'll help you overcome the lethargy and inaction in the future.

Just my two cents, I hope they're useful.

>>21508488
>Like when I thought of a story
That is a plot, I am talking individual ideas, full plots will generally not allow you to find a common thread and full plots are far more difficult to fill in than it is to build up from smaller ideas. Mainly you need to stop reducing things to cliches like "brainstorming" as in see the cliche for what it is instead of just a cliche. Get a notebook or use your phone or whatever and write down every little idea you have which seems interesting to you, occasionally read through it and look for that common thread. Stop thinking so rigidly about story ideas, stories are built up from many smaller ideas.
